p: Many developing countries are expanding sugarcane plantation areas to produce biofuel, as a strategy to reduce their dependence on petroleum, to increase opportunities for the agricultural sector, and to mitigate global warming [ 50]. In Brazil, the creation of the pro-alcohol program, developed to replace a significant percentage of fossil-fuel consumption with ethanol produced from sugarcane [ 51], was triggered by an increase of 428% in oil prices in 1973 [ 52]. This program and the recent interest in alternative energy sources have fostered an expansion in the extent of sugarcane cultivation, making the country the world’s leader in ethanol production [ 53] and sugarcane (~ 490 million tons per year) exports [ 54]. The majority of this production (~74%) comes from the southeastern region, with the state of São Paulo producing 60% of the total yield [ 55, 56].
